title: Did the ancient Greeks use the words 'anax' or 'basileus' the same way that we use the word 'king,' as both a title AND a term? (e.g., 'That's Basileus Alexendros; he's our basileus.') - Quora

response.answer_text: Once again, I’ve descended to Wikipedia. Basileus - Wikipedia Titles are problematic in any case, and I don’t recall Achilles as being described as anything but swift of foot, at least before his name. One bit from Wikipedia: The word can be contrasted with wanax, another word used more specifically for "king" and usually meaning "High King" or "overlord". With the collapse of Mycenaean society, the position of wanax ceases to be mentioned, and the basileis (the plural form) appear the topmost potentates in Greek society. In the works of Homer wanax appears, in the form ánax, mostly in descriptions of Zeus (ánax andrōn te theōn te, "king of men and of the gods") and of very few human monarchs, most notably Agamemnon. Otherwise the term survived almost exclusively as a component in compound personal names (e.g., Anaxagóras, Pleistoánax) and is still in use in Modern Greek in the description of the anáktoron/anáktora ("[place or home] of the ánax"), i.e. of the royal palace. The latter is essentially the same word as  wa-na-ka-te-ro, wanákteros, "of the wanax/king" or "belonging to the wanax/king", used in Linear B tablets to refer to various craftsmen serving the king (e.g. the "palace", or royal, spinner, or the ivory worker), and to things belonging or offered to the king (javelin shafts, wheat, spices, precincts etc.). Most of the Greek leaders in Homer's works are described as basileís, which is conventionally rendered in English as "kings". However, a more accurate translation may be "princes" or "chieftains", which would better reflect conditions in Greek society in Homer's time, and also the roles ascribed to Homer's characters. Agamemnon tries to give orders to Achilles among many others, while another basileus serves as his charioteer. His will, however, is not to be automatically obeyed. In Homer the wanax is expected to rule over the other basileis by consensus rather than by coercion, which is why Achilles proudly and furiously rebels (the central theme of the Iliad) when he perceives that Agamemnon is unjustly bossing him around.

Inscription text ΒΑΣΙΛΕΩΣ ΑΛΕΞΑΝΔΡΟΥ (king Alexander's) Note that the Ancient Greek word order is usually “Alexander [the] King”, not “King Alexander” (though the coin does have the order “King Alexander”). You may well be familiar with another instance of such a title, a little further back in time. Sophocles’ play is called Oedipus The King: Oidipous Tyrannos (Oedipus Rex). (Granted, that title is late; Aristotle knew it as just Oidipous.)

The distinction between both titles lies in the in pre-historic origins of the Mycenaean “wanax”, which besides coming to be a sort of overlord over vassal like, smaller chieftains, “basileis”; was also thought to originally be the chief of the priestly class responsible for public rites and sacrifices. The wanax was originally a priest king, or chief priest, that later on became more of a chief warlord. The wanax had higher recognized status because they were also still the ceremonial chief of of the public rites, even though the priest class were, by the late bronze age, already a distinct class. Also the wanax had gained the right to bind lower chieftains into pledges of loyalty, and provision of troops in any military pursuits, foreign expeditions, or response against outside enemies. The position of the wanax though still had a connotation of being a bridge between the people and the divine, securing prosperity and well-being on their behalf. This title fell out of use after the late bronze age, Agean collapse, and was replaced fully by “baselious”, when the functions of the ruler became fully military and political, and separate from the functions of a priest class, and each region had become autonomous from any sort of overarching warlord.

So basically your question is if these words can be used both as adjectives and nouns. Running it in my head I can’t see why not. It is certainly ok in Modern Greek, but it seems that it is okay in Ancient Greek too. Of course, I don’t have a degree in Greek Philology and my knowledge of Ancient Greek is restricted to what I know from highschool, but I think it is ok.
